name: bamboo forestry, sustainable forest management | bamboo culm | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/28166/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of bamboo culms. Ecuador possesses about 50 different species of bamboo (Ruiz-Sanchet et al., 2021), of which about a fifth are endemic. The most commonly used species in the construction sector in Ecuador is Guadua angustifolia Kunth (caña Guadua angustifolia). Culms are normally extracted manually using a machete or a hatchet. The production of bamboo culms takes place at a bamboo forest or intermediary processing facility. In contrast to other countries, the production of bamboo culms in Ecuador does generally not make use of fertilisers and the culms are collected without mechanical support. When untreated, the service life of bamboo culms is approximately three years (De Flander and Rovers, 2009; Riaño et al., 2002). Due to their high water content (u= ca. 80 %), bamboo culms lack a direct application as a construction material. However, they are used for the production of bamboo poles which can be used directly for the construction of columns, beams, or struts and other bamboo-based construction materials. This dataset was developed by Estefania Barros, Kristi Padrón, Jonnathan Aguirre and Juan Sebastian Martines, under the lead of Prof. Paul Vanegas and Prof. Dolores Sucozhañay from the Inclusive Circular Economy and Sustainable Development Research Group of the University of Cuenca (ECI) in the frame of the CEELA (Strengthening capacities for energy efficiency in buildings in Latin America) project with the support of the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC). The figures origin mainly from an original dataset covering the geography CO and were adjusted with information provided by producers in Ecuador.;Ref:;Ruiz-Sanchez, E., Tyrrell, C. D., Londoño, X., Oliveira, R. P., and Clark, L. G.. (2021). Diversity, distribution, and classification of Neotropical woody bamboos (Poaceae: Bambusoideae) in the 21st Century. Botanical Sciences, 99(2), 198-228. Epub 08 de abril de 2021.https://doi.org/10.17129/botsci.2722;De Flander, K. and R. Rovers, One laminated bamboo-frame house per hectare per year. Construction and Building Materials, 2009. 23(1): p. 210-218. ;Riaño, N.M., et al., Plant growth and biomass distribution on Guadua angustifolia Kunth in relation to ageing in the Valle del Cauca – Colombia. Bamboo Science and Culture, 2002. 16(1): p. 43-51. 

From transformation of land into bamboo forest

This activity ends with bamboo culms (u=80%) at forest. The dataset includes the CO2 absorption from air and the land use for bamboo growth. The dataset does not include soil preparation, changes in carbon content in soil, use of pesticides or fertilisers, irrigation, plantation of seedlings, leaching of pesticides and fertilisers, infrastructure and use of mechanical equipment. Generally, none of them are used for the production of bamboo culms in Ecuador. According to Juan Carlos Salazar, agricultural engineer and Fabian Moreno, project manager of the International Bamboo and Rattan Organization (INBAR) Ecuador; the use of fertilizers is very unusual in natural bamboo forests, which represent approximately 97% of total bamboo area in Ecuador. The remaining 3% represent areas where bamboo is cultivated. There fertilizers are used once a year for two years. As bamboo generates shade and there is no competition with weeds, the use of herbicides is not common. Since branches and leaves stay on the ground in the forest, i.e. do not leave the system, they are neglected in this dataset.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/023:Gathering of non-wood forest products/0230:Gathering of non-wood forest products

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Time period referring to the data source: 2010-2023. Based on expert opinion data is considered to be valid at least up to 2028.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Current production technology. The International Bamboo and Rattan Organization (INBAR) Ecuador has been working with many bamboo producers throughout Ecuador, especially on the coast and in the Amazon. According to its project director, Fabián Moreno, most bamboo plantations are managed by small producers and the management of the plantations does not include the use of machinery or technical processes.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The input of bamboo is approximated with “wood, unspecified, standing”. The properties have been modified in order to reflect bamboo (Species: Guadua angustifolia Kunth). The data is based on Colombia (CO) original dataset due to the similarities with Ecuador and the fact that the bamboo specie is the same (Guadua Angustifolia Kuhnt).
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: This data is based on the dataset "bamboo forestry, sustainable forest management, CO, 2010-2020" available in ecoinvent v.3.9.1, due to its similarities with Ecuador and the fact that the bamboo species is the same (Guadua Angustifolia Kuhnt).

flow.name: bamboo culm
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/023:Gathering of non-wood forest products/0230:Gathering of non-wood forest products

exchanges.description: dry mass of the culm x gross calorific value of bamboo. The gross calorific value of bamboo refers to Guadua Angustifolia Kuhnt Bamboo, and is taken from the existing dataset "bamboo forestry, sustainable forest management, CO".

flow.name: Energy, gross calorific value, in biomass

exchanges.description: Value has been calculated based on an average yearly harvest of 30,625 kg per hectare. The value is specific for Guadua Angustifolia Kuhnt bamboo. Guadua Angustifolia Kunth is mostly of natural regeneration. The plant needs generally 8 years before being harvested (more than 9 cm in diameter). Once the forest produces commercial culms, the harvest can be annual. Even, depending on the cutting plan, it can take place twice a year. The harvest is selective of the culms that are 5 years old, but while these are cut, new shoots emerge (every year) so the harvest is continuous. Approximately 25% of the commercial culms are extracted each year.

Value has been calculated based on an average yearly harvest of 30,625 kg per hectare. The value is specific for Guadua Angustifolia Kuhnt bamboo. Guadua Angustifolia Kunth is mostly of natural regeneration. The plant needs generally 8 years before being harvested (more than 9 cm in diameter). Once the forest produces commercial culms, the harvest can be annual. Even, depending on the cutting plan, it can take place twice a year. The harvest is selective of the culms that are 5 years old, but while these are cut, new shoots emerge (every year) so the harvest is continuous. Approximately 25% of the commercial culms are extracted each year.
This input is used as a proxy to reflect bamboo, standing. The water properties have been adjusted according to the properties of the specific bamboo species (Dendrocalamus asper)

Carbon uptake from air into the product calculated based on the carbon content and dry mass of the product. Scaled to the molar mass from C to CO2. Branches and leaves are not taken into account, since they do not leave the system.

Value has been calculated based on an average yearly harvest of 30,625 kg per hectare. The value is specific for Guadua Angustifolia Kuhnt bamboo. Guadua Angustifolia Kunth is mostly of natural regeneration. The plant needs generally 8 years before being harvested (more than 9 cm in diameter). Once the forest produces commercial culms, the harvest can be annual. Even, depending on the cutting plan, it can take place twice a year. The harvest is selective of the culms that are 5 years old, but while these are cut, new shoots emerge (every year) so the harvest is continuous. Approximately 25% of the commercial culms are extracted each year.
